Pure Pap For Now People
So Carolyne Mas put on a pretty
good show last Saturday; or at least,
we heard she did - we can't say so firsthand because we didn't bother to go, and
apparently, neither did anyone else. The
total attendance was about 150, barely
the size of an art history or personality
theory lecture towards the end of a
semester. Well, hats off, Drs. Stanton and
Hogan: you both should arrange booking
deals with Chris Columbo...
There is no reason why concerts at
Hopkins need to be losing propositions.
The experience of the last twenty years
has shown not only that rock n' roll
is a marketable commodity, like toothpaste, but also that it is an extremely
lucrative commodity, like a med school
diploma. You need only to ask around
the concert circuit of small schools to see
that the concert situation at Hopkins is
truly dismal.
Two problems arise: first, there is
no guarantee of respectable ticket sales
for any show. True enough - sometimes
even sure bets fall through. But the
Caroline Mas show suffered from problems with publicity, not of talent. Mas is
clearly an unknown, something not

remedied by a few announcements
on 98 Schlock and some posters touting
her as the new Bruce Springsteen (almost
the Kiss of Death). Certainly ticket sales
would have benefitted from some attempt
at getting Mas heard on campus, either
through WJHU airplay or some album
giveaways.
Second problem: Well, fine, but
who's going to pay for all this? Again,
concerts are supposed to make money.
There are currently available a vast
repertoire of '13' bands -- proven groups
who, for various reasons, are out of the
commercial limelight but either continue,
or are about to muster, popular support.
Southside Johnny from 1976-1979
springs to mind, and the Boss himself
played this weasel circuit in the early
'70's. A cursory glance at an agent's
booking list reveals plenty of bands within
our price range who, with good publicity,
would be solid sellers.
For justifiable reasons, the Hopkins
concert-goer is a sluggish creature. After
too many Facedancers and Frank Webers,
the same old pap "rising young talent"
-- sounds kind of tired. It's up to the
promoter to get things rolling again.

Pure Pap For Now People
So Carolyne Mas put on a pretty
good show last Saturday; or at least,
we heard she did - we can't say so firsthand because we didn't bother to go, and
apparently, neither did anyone else. The
total attendance was about 150, barely
the size of an art history or personality
theory lecture towards the end of a
semester. Well, hats off, Drs. Stanton and
Hogan: you both should arrange booking
deals with Chris Columbo...
There is no reason why concerts at
Hopkins need to be losing propositions.
The experience of the last twenty years
has shown not only that rock n' roll
is a marketable commodity, like toothpaste, but also that it is an extremely
lucrative commodity, like a med school
diploma. You need only to ask around
the concert circuit of small schools to see
that the concert situation at Hopkins is
truly dismal.
Two problems arise: first, there is
no guarantee of respectable ticket sales
for any show. True enough - sometimes
even sure bets fall through. But the
Caroline Mas show suffered from problems with publicity, not of talent. Mas is
clearly an unknown, something not

remedied by a few announcements
on 98 Schlock and some posters touting
her as the new Bruce Springsteen (almost
the Kiss of Death). Certainly ticket sales
would have benefitted from some attempt
at getting Mas heard on campus, either
through WJHU airplay or some album
giveaways.
Second problem: Well, fine, but
who's going to pay for all this? Again,
concerts are supposed to make money.
There are currently available a vast
repertoire of '13' bands -- proven groups
who, for various reasons, are out of the
commercial limelight but either continue,
or are about to muster, popular support.
Southside Johnny from 1976-1979
springs to mind, and the Boss himself
played this weasel circuit in the early
'70's. A cursory glance at an agent's
booking list reveals plenty of bands within
our price range who, with good publicity,
would be solid sellers.
For justifiable reasons, the Hopkins
concert-goer is a sluggish creature. After
too many Facedancers and Frank Webers,
the same old pap "rising young talent"
-- sounds kind of tired. It's up to the
promoter to get things rolling again.

While taking time off might seem like an easy
decision to make, there are a number of people and

The other self-imposed obstacle to taking time off

"but I knew that whatever was holding me here wasn't

Sports Comment

Move It On Over, Chuck!
Oriole announcer Chuck
Thompson recently commented,
"More ladies than ever are going
to the ballpark these days." He
went on to add, "And they
aren't only going to stare at the
players, either. Quite a few of
our female spectators are knowledgeable about the game of
baseball."
What does he expect? The
Miss America Pageant, if held
every night, would attract few
constant viewers. Even the most
crush-ridden teenager, complete
with a T-shirt bearing her favorite's name and number, can't
help but pick up the rudiments
of her hero's game. The more
often she goes, the more she
learns - not to mention the trivia
she picks up from listening to
the announcers during televised
games.
The days of the stereotypical sports-stupid female, accompanying her boyfriend to a
game only to sigh of boredom
and ask dumb questions, are
Women are not only
over.
learning the fine points of sports
spectatorship, they are also
turning out in record numbers
for intense athletic competition.

For several years now, the
major universities (and many of
the minor ones) have worked
hard to upgrade women's athletics to equality with men's.
The gulf between the two is still
noticeable, but with improved
funding, staffing, and recruiting,
women's sports are coming into
their own. Here at Hopkins, the
turnout of freshman women for
various sports is a result fo this
new awareness.
Chuck Thompson may be
surprised by the number of

women with baseball savvy, but
he shouldn't be. The days of
stereotyped male/female recreations have come to an end.
Interests are chosen now on a far
more personal, individual basis.
A woman who takes an interest
in sports is no longer a "tomboy", or an "annie", she's a
team member or a fan.
Move over, Chuck. You
may be sharing your booth with
a female announcer - sooner
than you think.
